abstract.p: Correction of letter to editor in Nov 26 Arts and Leisure regarding veteran television comedians

block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Links to bin Laden Gnaw At F.B.I. in Cole Inquiry F.B.I. officials investigating the bombing of the destroyer Cole have kept open the possibility that the attack may have involved powerful figures in Yemen who have close ties to Osama bin Laden, the F.B.I.'s most-wanted terrorist.
INTERNATIONAL

Links to bin Laden Gnaw At F.B.I. in Cole Inquiry F.B.I. officials investigating the bombing of the destroyer Cole have kept open the possibility that the attack may have involved powerful figures in Yemen who have close ties to Osama bin Laden, the F.B.I.'s most-wanted terrorist.

Milosevic Named Party Leader A characteristically defiant Slobodan Milosevic staged his political comeback, winning re-election as leader of his Socialist Party of Serbia and denouncing as a coup the popular uprising that swept him from power last month.

Elections in Canada Prime Minister Jean Chretien is fighting for political survival, as his advantage over the conservative opposition narrows. If the Liberals fare poorly in Monday's elections, they will probably depose him, ending a decade of party leadership and seven years as prime minister.
SCIENCE/HEALTH

Climate Treaty Talks Fail Negotiations aimed at finishing a treaty to curb global warming broke down after two weeks of intense negotiations at The Hague, on disputes between American and European negotiators.
NATIONAL

Broward County Election Officials Complete Recount Weary election officials in Broward County finished their manual recount of ballots, cutting Gov. George W. Bush's lead over Vice President Al Gore in half.
Lawyers for Mr. Bush withdrew one lawsuit before filing new suits asking a judge to direct four Florida counties to reinstate the absentee ballots of overseas military voters.
The voting figures in Florida are expected to show a thin victory for Mr. Bush, but Mr. Gore's campaign has made it clear that he expects to fight on, whatever the result.
State lawmakers and elections officials around the country are proposing changes in voting procedures to reduce the potential for legal challenges in close elections.
The message from conservatives these days is simple and unified -- that the Democrats are trying to steal the election.
Care Centers Under Scrutiny The nation's largest chain of assisted living facilities has come under scrutiny over the quality of care and safety conditions at some of its centers.
Gifts for Those With Plenty Many Americans have amassed all the goods they need, so they are asking for gifts they can use up.
NEW YORK/REGION

Harlem Realty Renaissance Not Quite So Big After All Just as Harlem seems to be undergoing a renaissance, with property values rising and new stores and restaurants springing up, downtown real estate agencies, after taking a closer look, have quietly scrapped plans to open satellite offices in Harlem.

Yes, It Really Is More Crowded If New York feels more crowded these days, it's because it is. There are more people living in the city, more people working in it and more people coming to visit. And it's not just a matter of numbers; affluence intensifies the impression.
Neediest Cases
OBITUARIES
Keith Mant A pathologist who provided evidence from exhumed corpses that was used to send a number of Nazi doctors to the gallows after World War II, he was 81.
Chess
